PROJECT OBJECTIVE: The proposed project would have three principal objectives: (i) restore degraded State-owned forest and pasture areas and promote their sustainable use; (ii) promote the conservation of natural forest ecosystems; and (iii) take the initial steps in the transition of the forestry/pasture sector to a market economy, separating commercial from regulatory functions and establishing mechanisms for self-financing of the commercial activities. The project would support institutional and policy reforms of Albania's forest and pasture sector and provide resources for investments in the five components described below. PROJECT DESCRIPI'ION: The project, to be implemented over six years (including a one-year pre-project phase), would contain the following five investment components: * Institutional Development, including (i) reorganization and strengthening of DGFP by decentralizing its management structure to the prefecture level, developing capacity to manage its new roles in communal forest/ pasture and general pasture administration, and introducing skills required for operating in a market economy; (ii) support for training, education and research in forestry and pastures; (iii) project management; (iv) project environmental management; and (v) technical assistance. * Improved State Forest Manaaement, including: (i) strengthening the capacity of field services to manage and protect State forests; (ii) resuming forest management planning; (iii) reforestation of sensitive areas; (iv) pre-commercial thinnings; and (v) forest protection and pest monitoring. * Forest Roads Rehabilitation and Maintenance, involving the rehabilitation and subsequent maintenance of 350 km of degraded existing forest roads.
 iv * Management of Communal Forest and Pasture Areas involving: (i) the implementation of a pilot project in three communes; (ii) development of improved management plans for forests and pastures in 27 additional communes; (iii) funding of selected communal investment projects; and (iv) establishment of a data base on communally managed forests and pastures. PROJECT BENEFITS AND RISKS: Benefits. In relation to the principal project objectives the project's activities are expected to generate the following benefits: (i) economic production benefits from restoring degraded forest and pastures; (ii) direct and indirect environmental benefits from preventing losses from soil erosion, and enhancing biodiversity and ecosystems protection and preservation of protected areas; and (iii) institutional and policy improvements that are expected to lead to higher degrees of efficiency and sustainability of use of a public renewable resource, with provisions to safeguard stakeholder interests and the creation of positive externalities through continued, but more focused public sector involvement. Key indicators for progress would be: control of illegal harvesting operations; application of new-style forest management methodology that would be geared to multiple and sustainable forest use; achievement of the sector's financial viability which in turn will depend on competitive marketing and trade liberalization; and creation of an autonomous Forest Corporation to deal with commercial, efficient exploitation of the resource. Risks. Project risks regarding technical aspects of forest management, road rehabilitation and communal forest and pasture management are considered low. Albania possesses the basic expertise to deal with technical aspects of forest use. The main risks of the project relate to uncertainties about the implementation of the institutional and policy reforms. Critical elements are, first, the State must regain control over forest management and exploitation. To this end, the project focuses on the implementation of a monitorable action plan to reduce illegal logging and the early strengthening of the administrative capacity through the provision of physical inputs and staff reorientation and training. Second is the need to achieve financial viability and sustainability within the sector. To this end, market-oriented procedures, both in domestic marketing and external trade, would be introduced to help overcome the current under-use and under-valuation of the forest resource. Third is the need to improve the technical and economic efficiency of forest and pasture operations. To this end, the project would support the separation of commercial forest and pasture operations as the responsibility of a financially autonomous enterprise from the regulatory and policy activities that would remain part of the Government administration. The risk to achieve the policy and institutional goals is mitigated by a relative long adjustment and reform period of up to three years. This period would be used to build capacity for dealing with the issues, achieve consensus within Albania about the longer term arrangements for use of the forest and pasture resources, and refine concepts and planning for the policy, legal and institutional actions. This process would be helped by a proposed high-level seminar in year two to review strategies proposed for the development of the sector, and the mid-term review of the Project. The latter would be used to assess progress made in resolving the above critical aspects and, depending on the outcome and achievements, to confirm or adjust the design and scope of project activities, in

INTRODUCTION 1.1 Albania is going through a difficult transition from a strictly enforced centrally planned economy to democratic and market economic conditions. Major structural adjustments involving agriculture, enterprises and banking, and the provision of Government services, have been completed or are under way. Reforms of economic policies have led to widespread liberalization of pricing, external trade, and domestic marketing, making Albania one of the most open economies among the countries in transition. Land and related assets that once were nationalized are now almost completely divested, either through restitution to former owners (in urban areas), or through distribution to individual farming families (former cooperative or State farm agricultural land). Preparations are under way to give full ownership rights to the new land holders. A Mass Privatization Program has been initiated to privatize most of the remaining State-owned enterprises and assets. 1.2 Forestry is a sector in Albania that, so far, has not benefited from the above structural changes and that has been rather negatively affected by the transition. While the harvesting and processing activities in the sector now take place through privatized or newly formed enterprises, forest management is still bound into an old-fashioned State bureaucracy. Forest management and protection have been particularly affected by the sudden end of the former command and control approach. Uncontrolled harvesting has developed, continuing administered trade, pricing and marketing procedures generate inefficiencies and distortions, and fiscal austerity has reduced the budget for the forest administration to the point where it can only cover the payment of salaries and a few operational costs. A large backlog has developed for investments in updating forest management plans, regeneration of harvested forest areas, maintenance and protection of forests, rehabilitation of forest roads, replacement of worn-out transport and equipment, upgrading of offices, and introducing more efficient market and incentive- oriented procedures. i.3 By law, Albania's forests, as well as pasture areas, are State-owned.' Forests comprise some one million ha, or 38% of the country's land area, and together with over 0.4 million ha of State pasture areas, about half of Albania's land area is administered by the Directorate General of Forests and Pastures (DGFP) in the Ministry of Agriculture and Food (MAF). In spite of this vast natural resource base, the contribution of forests and pastures to the country's economy has remained negligible. The sector continues to be oriented toward meeting domestic requirements (which during the economic transition phase shrank). Criteria of economic efficiency are only slowly taking hold in forest and pasture management. Yet the potential exists to restore the sectors' productive capacities. The sector could not only become self-financing, but a net contributor to the Government. It could also play important roles for rural employment, industrial development, and for generating environmental benefits. I Some 60,000 ha of State forest have been identified to have been owned by private persons or institutions before 1945 and are proposed for restitution. The forest law (1992) and the pasture law (1995) permit State forest and pasture land to be transferred to communes for usufruct.

In 1990, forestry accounted for only 6 percent of the combined value of output of agriculture, livestock and forestry although forest land occupied 40 percent of the total land area. Livestock accounted for 36 percent of the output value; however, statistical data for livestock is not broken down between output from agricultural land, from natural pastures and meadows, and from non-land based animal husbandry such as pigs and intensive poultry. FOREST AND PASTURE RESOURCES 2.2 Resource Base. Albania's total land area of 28,750 km2 is divided into three main ecological zones: the coastal plain zone, with a southern area and a central and northern area; the hilly transition sub-mountainous zone; and the mountainous zone. A more precise division shows five phyto-climatic areas: (i) the Mediterranean shrub zone with broadleaved and conifer areas, (ii) the oak zone, (iii) the beech zone, (iv) the fir zone, and (v) the alpine zone. Forests are mainly concentrated in the hilly and mountainous zone, as can be seen in Map IBRD 27266 at the end of this report. Climatic and soil conditions in Albania are favorable for forest and pasture growth. The annual precipitation varies considerably from about 800 mm/year in the hills and the coastal plains to over 2,000 mm/year in the mountain ranges. There is a dry period in the summer in the Mediterranean part of the country. 2.3 Albania has important and diverse forest resources. According to the 1995 reconnaissance survey and forest cover map carried out by FAO2, the total area of forest cover in Albania is an estimated 1,155,000 ha. This area includes (i) garrigue and maquis (310,000 ha), (ii) high scrubs and degraded 2 Prparation of a Forest Cover Map and Reconnaissance Forest Inventory of Albania. Broadleaved forests are mainly oak and beech, while coniferous forests are predominantly black pine with small patches of silver fir and mountain pine. Of the whole forest area, about 0.9 million ha, or 88 percent, is considered "productive" forest. The remaining 12 percent forest area is non-productive, although it fulfills protective and social functions. 2.4 Albania's pasture land comprises about 406,000 ha. Sixty percent of that area is classified as "winter pastures" covering lowland areas up to 1,500 m altitude; the remainder is "summer pasture" at higher altitudes (up to over 2,500 m) including alpine vegetation. The importance of the pasture resource is reflected in the fact that some 60 percent of the Albanian population is linked to pastoralism and herding, mainly of sheep and goats. 2.5 Forest Types. The main types of Albanian forests are the following: * High Forests. They are managed according to traditional methods with thinnings and regeneration felling aimed at value production. Regeneration is mainly done naturally by leaving seed trees. When satisfactory seed trees are not present, regeneration is done through replanting. High forest species are mainly beech (36%), black pine (23%), oak (17%), maritime pines, and other broadleaves and conifers. The rotation period of high forests is about 100-120 years; - [Coppice Forests. The main objective of coppice forests is to produce biomass for fodder (from oaks) and fuelwood through periodic cuts on a 40-50 year rotation. The dominating species is oak (82%), with small areas of beech (6%), and other broadleaves (11%); e Shrub Forests. They produce fuelwood and fodder from periodic cuts and are used for grazing livestock. Shrubs consist mainly of hornbeam (36%), arbutus (23%), and other broadleaves. Arbutus produces an excellent fuelwood. The recommended rotation is 20 years; * Forest Plantations. Reforestation by planting started in the 1960s. Over 100,000 ha were reforested by the end of 1991. Mostly pine species such as P. halepensis, P. nigra, P. pinaster, P. radiata and P. pinea, were planted. The broad-leaved species planted are Laurus nobilis, Juglans regia, Acer spp., Fraxinus spp., Tilia spp., and Betula spp. The plantations were mainly established in the areas degenerated by over-exploitation and heavy grazing; and * Farm Trees. Farm trees are scattered or in small plots on agricultural land (former State and Cooperative farm land) and around houses. They represent more than 11,000 ha equivalent, and mainly consist of poplars in the lowlands. Although almost all roadside trees were cut down during the political change, interest in planting and maintaining trees on the newly privatized farms is high. 2.6 Standing Timber Stock. During the review of the forestry sector by FAO/CP in early 19923, the total standing stock was an estimated 81 million m3, of which 64 million m3 was in high forests, 10 million m3 in coppice forests, and 7 million m3 in high scrubs, maquis and guarrigue. Commercial harvesting in high forests only started in the 1940s. The present age distribution in these forests is therefore uneven. Young stands of less than 20 years of age and mature stands of over 80 years are over-represented. Of the total area of beech, as much as 71 percent is over 80 years and 39 percent over 120 years. In coppice forests, young forests under 10 years are over-represented as well as forests over 40 years. According to statistics, the age distribution in shrub forests is balanced. 2.8 Ownership. Forests and pastures are State-owned, except small, privately owned areas. The 1992 forest law and the 1995 pasture law both allow usufruct of State forest and pasture areas by communes in their vicinity. The formal process of transferring forest and pasture land to communes has not yet started, while some informal privatization of pastures is going on. The Government is restituting to former owners some 60,000 ha of forests, and also additional pasture areas which had been nationalized under the communist regime. Trees planted on former State and cooperative farms, except orchards and wineyards, were distributed to farming families with the agricultural land, and are now privately owned. 2.9 Forest Use. Albanian forests are used for the production of wood and non-wood products, principally for the domestic market. Annual removals of wood during 1971-1980 averaged 4.6 million -n3, about half as roundwood, one third as fuelwood, and the remainder as saw logs. In the 1980s, cuts have decreased to between 2.5 - 2.9 million m3, with fuelwood taking up a larger share. During the transition period in the 1990s, official removal of all wood has been declining from 1.5 million m3 in 1991 to below 0.6 million m3 in 1994. For the 1995/96 harvesting year, 0.6 million m3 (of which 0.4 million m3 comprised of timber and 0.2 million m3 of fuelwood) was offered for sale in auctions, but less than half of this volume was sold due to lack of demand. However, simultaneously, self-collection and illegal harvesting have increased. For instance, recorded illegal cuts amounted to 0.746 million m3 in 1991, 0.915 million m3 in 1992, and 0.380 million m3 per year in 1993 and 1994. According to appraisal mission estimates, recorded and unrecorded illegal cuttings have likely exceeded legal harvesting in 1995. It includes uncontrolled wood-cutting and overgrazing, and is mostly concentrated in the last five years. Field observations in 1995 suggest, however, that an increasing share of illegal cutting is used as industrial timber. FOREST MANAGEMENT, HARVESTING, FOREST ROADS AND WOOD INDUSTRY 2.12 Forest Inventory and Management Plans. Forest inventory and subsequent development of forest management plans (FMPs) used to be carried out by the Forest Inventory and Management Section of the Forest and Pasture Research Institute (FPRI). For the high forest, inventory was carried out on one tenth of the total area every year, with a sampling intensity of 10 percent; FMPs were then prepared for the inventoried area. Thus, about 40,000 ha of high forests were planned for the next 10-year period every year. FMPs were developed at the level of management units, with an average size of 3,000 ha (ranging from 1,000 to 5,000 ha). The main aim of forest management planning in the high forests is to achieve an even age distribution in the management unit following the sustained yield principle. The annual allowable cut is calculated based on the current annual increment of that management unit. The development of FMPs has stopped since the late 1980s, which leaves about 75 percent of the high forests in need of updating their FMPs. For the coppice and shrubs, a nationwide inventory over the total area was made every 10th year, with a sampling intensity of 5 percent; a simplified management plan was developed subsequently. The last inventory and simplified management plan of the coppice and shrubs was done in 1985. No resources are available to update the simplified management plan of coppice and shrub forests, which was due in 1995. 2.13 Forest Regeneration. About 90 percent of the forests in Albania are natural, and used to be regenerated naturally. In the high forests, natural regeneration is carried out over 20-25 years for broad- leaved species and 15-20 years for conifers. Natural regeneration was usually achieved through a successive cutting program including: (i) a preparatory cutting that removes 25-30 percent of the growing stock; (ii) a seed cutting, about 8-10 years following the preparatory cutting, that removes 25-30 percent of the existing growing stock after a good seed year has been observed; and (iii) a final cutting that is carried out when regrowth reaches about one meter height, 10-15 years after seed cutting. Careful implementation of this program, together with routine support to natural regeneration including complementary seeding, has been discontinued over the last five to 10 years. In about 15,000 ha of harvested high forests, the regeneration is either incomplete or even absent. In the coppice, shrub, and maquis, regeneration is achieved by coppicing, after clear cutting of the stand. The success of regeneration of coppice and shrubs has been negatively affected in areas close to villages under high pressure from livestock and fuelwood collection. 2.14 Forest Maintenance. Regular maintenance of young stands in the high forest, covering about 60,000 ha, has not been carried out in the 1990s. Pre-commercial thinnings have not been carried out, and commercial thinnings have been carried out at a very low rate, representing only 5 percent of the total harvest. This practice does not comply with FMPs under which thinnings should be carried out at

However, this rate has not been observed. 2.15 Forest Protection. Monitoring of the health and protection of Albanian forests against pests and diseases has been inadequate. The most serious insect attacks are caused by Thaumatopoea pityocampa, the pine processionary moth that has spread over about 45,000 ha in black pine stands since it first appeared in 1985. Other important insect pests include Dioryctria splendidela and Evetria buoliana in pine plantation, and Tortrix viridana and Lymantria dispar in oak stands. Serious fungi attacks are caused by Endothia parasitica on chestnut, and Microsphaera alphitoides in oak stands. 2.16 Forest Harvesting Levels. As indicated above (para. 2.9 and Table 2.2), the level of actual harvesting in the past has tended to exceed the AAC calculated by the FPRI. Most of this over-harvesting has taken place in the coppice and shrub forests, but high forests close to habitations have also been affected. In view of the obvious high utilization of coppice and shrub forests, and the fact that they have not been completely degraded, there are reasons to believe that their production capacity has been underestimated in the calculation of the AAC. However, in 1994 and 1995, the breakdown and restructuring of Government-owned harvesting and processing enterprises, combined with severe budget constraints of DGFP and a closed domestic market, led to the inverse situation that actual legal harvesting has dropped significantly below the AAC. 2.17 Besides the over-exploitation in the past, there have been imbalances in the concentration of the fellings. About 1 I percent of the growing stock is standing in areas not accessible by forest roads. This amounts to more than nine million m3 of industrial wood on 66,000 ha. However, even the forests inaccessible by forest roads have not remained fully intact as most of these forests have been exploited by the local people. 2.18 Harvesting Methods. (i) Most of the wood harvesting in State forests is carried out in mountainous areas, where the terrain is difficult, as 80 percent of the forests grow on slopes of 20-50 percent inclination. Harvesting is based almost exclusively on the assortment method where the trees are made into short assortments in the forest before off-road transportation. Average saw logs are four meters long. Big dimension plywood logs can be even shorter. The minimum length is one meter for fuelwood, parquet blocks, pulpwood and similar assortments. Long lengths are seldom used due to difficulties in loading and unloading. (ii) Farmers and villagers use both the assortment method and the stemwood method, where only the delimbing is done before off-road transportation. Fuelwood is mostly hand carried or loaded on donkeys. Besides high productivity over short distances, donkeys and mules, mostly used for skidding stems for construction timber, can move in conditions which are impossible for skidders and other machines. 2.19 Forest Roads. The total length of Albania's forest roads is 3,518 km (as of 1993) from which 63 percent (2,237 km) has been built in high forests (1,727 km permanent, 510 km non-permanent). In the coppice forests the length of roads is 1,281 km (508 km permanent, 773 km nonpermanent). Shrub forests are served mainly by public roads because they are located near villages and along public roads. As shrub land has little economic significance, no special roads have been made for them, although access roads can cross them. Practically all forest roads were constructed after the 1950s at the rate of nearly 100 km annually. Forest roads have been constructed according to Albanian road classes IV and V. On average, the density of forest roads is 3.5 m/ha. However, the density is normally increased to 15-20 m/ha in areas where final harvesting is taking place. 2.20 The main problem regarding forest roads in Albania is the degradation of the existing network of class IV and V roads. The actual degree and extent of forest roads degradation is being surveyed by
 Albania Forestry Project Page -8 - Staff Appraisal Repoit the DGFP. At this stage, an estimated 25 percent of the existing network needs rehabilitation work in order to limit further degradation. Another problem is that many areas are not accessible to truck transport and commercial harvesting due to lack of suitable roads and steep slopes. Some of these forests are therefore mature, or over-mature, considering the rotations normally applied in Albania. The FPRI has estimated that there are at least 66,000 ha of comparatively large contiguous areas which could be opened for harvesting. The growing stock of these areas exceeds 13 million m3 of which the share of industrial wood is more than 9 million m3. However, some of these areas without access roads are expected to harbor significant environmental values and interests. While the "1995 Ecological Survey of High Forest Areas4" identified and categorized the future use of these areas, detailed site-specific environmental assessments need to be carried out for those areas that could be opened up for future harvesting. However, in view of the current lack of capacity in the forest administration to control illegal logging, update and implement FMPs, and carry out environmental assessments and effective environmental management, construction of new forest roads and opening up of new harvesting areas is not included under the current forestry project. 2.21 Harvesting Enterprises. The former State-owned logging enterprises at the district level under DGFP have all but collapsed in the transition process towards a market economy. New private sector enterprises, often formed by employees and with assets of the former DGFP enterprises, have emerged and carry out harvesting operations under competitive bidding for forest lots (auctions of stumpage wood), in accordance with DGFP's forest management plans and under technical supervision by DGFP district staff. However, due to the small number and size of competent harvesting and trading enterprises, and the resultant lack of competition, wood is mostly sold at the minimum price set by DGFP (see Table 2.3 below). 2.22 Wood Processing Industry. In the past, about 35 wood processing enterprises had been producing various products, including pulp and paper, sawn timber, veneers, plywood, particle board and chipboard, parquet and furniture. The installed capacity of these wood industries (originally about one million m' of industrial wood was processed annually) is in excess of the sustainable forest supply (currently estimated at 0.6 million m3 of industrial timber). However, plant closures and managerial difficulties during the transition and privatization, combined with old fashioned technology, production methods and products, have resulted in significant under-use of this installed capacity. In 1995, the domestic industry only processed some 0.1 million m3. Many enterprises have closed down. Lack of coordination between the felling quota (AAC) and the actual processing capacity of the industry has also led to serious wastage of raw material, as logs have been felled but not processed in time to prevent decaying. Furthermore, haphazard trade policies which included export taxes, quotas, bans and other restrictions, have aggravated the situation of over supply of the domestic market with industrial wood. Most of the enterprises have now been privatized and a few of them entered into joint ventures with foreign partners. The remaining ones are slated to be liquidated or included in Albania's Mass Privatization Program being implemented in 1995 and 1996. Imports of timber, both unprocessed and processed, are uneconomic due to low domestic raw material prices and an import tariff (30%) on furniture. Albania's exports of forest products were affected negatively by haphazard and inconsistent policies in the recent years. In early 1995, export quotas and license requirements were in place for logs, firewood, charcoal, edgings and beams. In July 1995, these quantitative restrictions were replaced by an export ban on logs, poles, sawn wood and fuelwood, while exports of all other forest products, including charcoal, were liberalized. The restrictive trade regime prevents Albania from realizing the revenue and benefit potential from its forest resource. It also tends to preserve imbalances in spatial resource use and technical inefficiencies in the logging and processing industries. It provides the wood-processing industry with a non-targeted subsidy in the form of cheaper wood. The elimination of trade barriers to allow domestic prices to rise close to international levels is needed to make Albania's forestry sector economically and financially viable, in particular, in a situation where the domestic industry is temporarily unable to process all timber that is and can be harvested sustainably within the AAC, provided that suitable environmental safeguards are being introduced. These environmental safeguards are currently not in place due to lack of capacity to control illegal logging. In this situation, temporary trade restrictions, although imperfect and distortive, can contribute to reduce the risk of over-exploitation of the resource. In the medium-term, the rather distortive tradition to attempt regulating harvesting through trade barriers should be replaced by efficient forest management and liberalization of external trade, including tariffs that are consistent with those for other sectors of the economy. 2.24 Domestic Marketing and Pricing. The most common method for timber sale by DGFP is the auction of standing timber in relatively small areas, typically less than 500 ha, that are accessible by existing forest roads. Floor prices (see Table 2.3 below) are applied that have been derived by estimating the cost to the State for producing the relevant category of wood over a given rotation period and taking account of "reasonable international standards." Due to lack of demand and competition (para. 2.21 above), most sales are in fact closed at or slightly above these floor prices. In 1994 and 1995, the average floor price in Albania was about $13 per m3, which compares to stumpage values of $40 in Central Europe, and up to $60 in Southern Europe. This method, which does not involve a price bid for the standing timber, has so far only been used in isolated cases. The contract is awarded on the basis of the quality of the proposal for forest management. The winning contractor then purchases timber at existing floor prices adjusted downwards to reflect the magnitude of

A concession has the main advantage that it removes the need for outlays by the Government for investments needed to open up new areas, and that it generates additional revenues from harvesting. However, this method in its present form suffers from the main disadvantage that the criteria by which proposals for concessions are to be evaluated are not easily measurable, and the selection of contractors is bound to raise questions about the impartiality of the process. Meticulous administrative processes are also required to avoid environmental risks. Albania's forest and environmental administrations are presently clearly not capable to properly handle contracts of this nature. 2.26 In the longer term, the principle of auction sales of timber, if truly competitive and accompanied by an improved monitoring capacity to safeguard environmental values and long-term productivity of the forest, should provide reliable indicators of the financial or economic viability of timber production in each forest unit. It would be a flexible method to deal with issues of spatial variations in costs and also the cost inter-dependence between fuelwood and timber production. E. FOREST AND PASTURE POLICY AND LEGISLATION 2.27 Previous Forest Policies. Key aspects of Albania's forestry policy in the 1980s, though not fully implemented, were: (i) reduce felling to a level which is compatible with sustained growth of the forest; (ii) redirect harvesting from low yielding forests to over-mature stands; (iii) increase forest plantations, especially coniferous ones; and (iv) reduce waste and inefficiency in logging and wood processing by improved technology. The underlying law (Law No. 6607 of 1968, modified in 1983 and 1990) was designed for the operation of a centrally planned system of forest management. Authorizations were required for any forest related activity, i.e., logging, trade of wood, grazing and construction works in the forest. This policy was limited to the production aspect of forestry and did not touch on other relevant aspects, such as forest ownership and user rights, the role of the State in forestry activities, and people's involvement. 2.28 Forest Legislation. The Law on "Forestry and the Forest Police Service" (No. 7223 of October 13, 1992) is today Albania's primary law on forestry. It places greater importance on environmental issues and economic management. The law defines the country's forest estate ("forest fund") which comprises State, communal and private forests. State forest management remains the responsibility of the forest administration, though the law does not specify the methods. Management of private forest is not covered under this law. Communal forests are a newly introduced category that, while still State-owned land, have the possibility of management by communes, jointly with the forest administration. Private forests are those found on private land.5 Various subsidiary texts to the forestry law have also been issued. These include regulations for the exploitation of forests, decisions on the setting of stumpage and other forest fees, guidelines for auctions of standing wood, instructions for protection against forest fires, a regulation containing the principles for the selection and establishment of protected areas, and a regulation for the use of forests for recreational purposes. A "Wild Fauna and Hunting Protection" law (No. 7875 of November 23, 1994) contains environmental provisions for wildlife which are not contained in the forest law. It provides for the preparation of wildlife management plans and constitutes an appropriate framework. S In addition to existing pnvate (agricultural) land with forest flora, the Govemment has amended (May 1995) the forest law to allow restitution of an estimated 60,000 ha of forst lands that were nationalized during the communist regime (1945-1989) (see also pam. 2.8).

The Law on "Pasture and Grazing Land" (No. 7917 of April 13, 1995) is relevant for land covered with grass and shrub used for pasture and mowing that belongs neither to the agricultural land fund nor to the forest fund. It divides pastures and meadows into (i) State pasture land administered by DGFP; (ii) State pasture land for general use, administered by the corresponding municipality and commune; and (iii) private land, including group ownership. This Law goes further than the above forest law towards decentralizing user rights to local government institutions and allowing participation of the affected population. Communes are fully responsible for the technical and financial management of communal pastures. Communes can also establish ten-year lease contracts with persons interested in using communal pastures. DGFP's role in the system of communal and private pastures is to approve changes in the use of such land, provide technical assistance (extension services) against payment, and to protect pastures and meadows from damages. 2.30 Environmental Legislation. A Law on "Envirorunental Protection" (No. 7664 of January 21, 1993) is relevant to forestry and pastures since it requires environmental impact assessments and licenses for activities that may have a significant impact on the environment. Environmental licenses, issued by the environmental authority (see para. 2.38 below), are required for a wide variety of activities such as building of infrastructure, exploration and exploitation of soil, forests, wildlife and fish, and dealing with hazardous substances. Draft regulations have been prepared for environmental impact assessments which, additional to the necessity of issuing licenses, are to be prepared at the request of the environmental or local authorities, principally by the Committee for Environmental Protection (CEP). These regulations provide for public participation at each step in the process. The environmental law also requires compliance by Albania with "generally accepted norms and principles" of international environmental law. A draft law on the "Protection of Nature and Biological Diversity" is under discussion in Albania which should reflect the national strategy on nature and biodiversity conservation for which preparations have been initiated in Albania. 2.31 Key Policy Objectives. Albania's draft Constitution reconfirms State ownership over forest and pasture land that has historically always been a national asset. The basic legal and policy framework for the economic and sustainable development of the sector is in place. However, the forest law needs fine- tuning to clarify both the production and conservation objectives of forest management, user and ownership rights, in particular with the intended transfer of forests to communal management, and the sustainable and multiple use of forests on private land. The country also lacks an explicit statement of the principles of its forest and pasture policy, that specify its long-term goals, principles and operational directions. However, policy objectives can be derived from the above legal framework, the actions already taken, and also from the Government's involvement in the design of the proposed project. The national objectives are seen in the intention of the Government to develop the sector in three major thrusts: (i) develop the sector's economic potential on a sustainable basis; (ii) ensure that sound environmnental and nature conservation criteria are applied in this process; and (iii) reduce Government involvement in the sector through divestiture of enterprises and functions, transfer of user rights, and institutional reforms. F. INSTITUTIONAL FRAMEWORK 2.32 Directorate General of Forests and Pastures (DGFP). Forests and pastures in Albania are the responsibility of DGFP which reports to the Minister of Agriculture and Food. Wood processing is part of the portfolio of the Ministry of Industry, Transport and Trade, after an intermittent assignment to DGFP in 1991 and 1992. DGFP has its headquarters in Tirana, with operational sections for control, pastures, fauna, forest protection, forest extraction, silviculture, and economics and privatization. Headquarters staff totals 32, of whom, 23 are university graduates and five technicians. Until 1994,

District offices are responsible for implementing forest management plans and applying regulations. In particular, they are in charge of establishing forest plantations, marking trees for exploitation, organizing sales and auctions and supervising harvesting operations. They also have a policing function and are to enforce the forest legislation. Furthermore, DGFP district offices are in charge of managing national parks and other protected areas which coincide with specific forest sectors. In 1995, DGFP field offices at the district level and below had a staff of 1595, of whom 425 were university graduates and 991 technicians. 2.33 Until recently, DGFP oversaw 18 State pasture enterprises. In addition to its forest offices, these pasture enterprises had a staffing of some 270, of whom 86 were professionals and 162 technicians. With the passage of the pasture law, the structure of separate pasture offices is being discontinued. About 70 percent of the pasture staff will be integrated into the forest districts. The remainder will be assigned to communes, in particular, in the areas of winter pastures that are expected to be transferred to communes over time. 2.34 Forest Management Implementation. The overall capacity of DGFP to manage State forests has been considerably hampered due to harsh financial constraints since the early 1990s. Although Albanian foresters are well trained, and used to manage State forests satisfactorily in the past, they lack the basic equipment, infrastructure, and financial resources to perform their duties as managers of state forests. These duties are administering the State forest and pastoral domain, implementing forest management plans, organizing wood harvesting and marketing, organizing grazing on forest and pasture land, carrying out investments in forests and pastures, caring for nurseries, enforcing environmental law and policies, managing hunting and fishing, and administering budgets and revenues, and employment of staff and workers. 2.35 Forest Research. (a) The Forest and Pasture Research Institute (FPRI) is responsible for: (i) applied research activities in the field of forestry and pasture management, (ii) conducting forest inventories, and (iii) preparing forest and pasture management plans. Administratively, the Institute is attached to the Directorate of Science and Qualification at the Ministry of Agriculture and Food. It has five research sections, the subjects of which are: forestry and genetics, management, inventory, harvesting and pastures, protection (pests, fires), and oil-bearing and medicinal plants. In 1993, the Institute had 49 professional staff, but its activities have been very much reduced in recent years due to lack of funding. In 1994, the Institute, under contract with the World Bank, carried out the Ecological Survey of Selected High Forest Areas that significantly influenced the design of the forestry project by eliminating interventions to open up new harvesting areas. (b) The Forestry Faculty of the University of Agriculture in Tirana is also involved in forestry research. 2.36 Forestry Education and Training. High level education in forestry is the responsibility of the Forestry Faculty in the University of Agriculture in Tirana which also includes the faculties of agronomy, 6 The 12 prefect forest offices will also double as district forest offices, thus reducing the latter to 24.

The curricula are organized over 5 years according to two profiles: (i) forestry generalists, with a sub-specialization in silviculture or forest exploitation; and (ii) wood technology specialists. The target is to graduate 20 students a year for the first profile and 10 a year for the second. 2.37 Intermediate training in forestry is the responsibility of the Forest Technician School located in Shkoder. The present situation of the school is a cause for concern, as it lacks means to perform. Until 1994, the school had the same curricular paths as the Forestry Faculty, but now there are three divisions or subject areas: (i) silviculture and greening; (ii) forest harvesting; (iii) furniture. Each division recruits 40-50 new students per year who have completed 8 years of primary education. There are 31 teachers, of whom 6 are forestry engineers and one is a wood industry specialist. The length of curriculum is 5 years for the first two divisions and 4 years for the third. About 15-30 percent of the students who graduate from the Technician School enter the Forestry Faculty in Tirana for further academic education. 2.38 Environmental Institutions. The Committee for Environmental Protection (CEP) is the central authority for coordination of environmental affairs. Administratively, CEP is placed under the Ministry of Health and the Enviromment. CEP gives final approval for environmental impact assessments. CEP has a small professional staff of eight, including the chairman and seven specialists divided over three directorates. Forestry is grouped under the Natural Resource Protection and Soil Rehabilitation Directorate. It is the Directorate's responsibility to monitor government activities in its functional areas and register objections when environmental concerns are flouted. The Directorate head also represents environmental interests on a commission that select larger forest exploitation projects. CEP was strengthened in 1994 with the establishment of Environmental Regional Agencies at the Prefectures. Other environmental institutions of note include the Museum of Natural Sciences, the Faculty of Natural Sciences at the University of Tirana, and the Institute for Biological Research. There are also a number of environmental NGOs: the leading ones active in public awareness efforts are the "Society for the Protection and Preservation of the Natural Environment in Albania", and the "Albanian Society for the Protection of Birds and Mammals." 2.39 Local Government. Under Albania's decentralization policy, a new structure of central and local government is being established to give more autonomous decision-making, management and responsibility to communes (and municipalities for the large cities). Twelve prefectures, appointed by the Council of Ministers, represent the central Government within new administrative-territorial units and coordinate and supervise the work of ministries. Communes that comprise two or more villages are the lowest level of local government with legal status and own budget. They are represented by communal councils whose members are elected directly by the population. Districts are made up of several related communes and are represented by district councils that are also directly elected. New pasture legislation has now been passed allowing for the transfer of State assets to communes, and the rules for managing communal assets are under preparation. Concerning forests and pastures, the elected council has the responsibilities of managing the resources of the commune or municipality; of taking the measures for the protection and revival of the environment; and of encouraging private initiatives. RATIONALE FOR IDA INVOLVEMENT 2.44 The updated Country Assistance Strategy of the Bank (1995) emphasizes infrastructure development and selected projects for poverty alleviation as priorities for development. Thus, IDA's involvement in Albania's forest and pasture sector would mainly be to: help develop a sound overall policy and institutional framework, re-orient education and training for forest professionals, improve State forest management and use to increase its productive capacity and halt the ongoing degradation, introduce communal management of forest and pasture areas under a participatory approach, and improve management of protected areas on a pilot basis, while ensuring sound environmental practices in all activities.
 ALBANIA FORESTRY PROJECT CHAPTER III. THE PROJECT A. PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND SUMMARY DESCRIPTION 3.1 Objectives. The project would have three principal objectives: (i) restore degraded State-owned forest and pasture areas and promote their sustainable use; (ii) promote conservation of natural forest ecosystems; and (iii) take the initial steps in the transition of the forestry/pasture sector to a market economy, separating commercial from regulatory functions and establishing mechanisms for self-financing of the commercial activities. 3.2 Summary Description. The project would support institutional and policy reforms of Albania's forest and pasture sector and provide resources for investment in the following five main components: (i) institutional development of the forest/pasture administration including related training, education and research and the establishment of a project environmental management unit; (ii) improved management of State forests; (iii) rehabilitation of forest roads; (iv) management of communal forest and pasture areas; and (v) management of protected areas. B. DETAILED FEATURES Institutional Reform [See also the chart in Appendix 2, and Annex A of the Supporting Volume] 3.3 Approach. Over a three year period, the project would support the transition from the current departmentally organized, all-encompassing forest and pasture administration, to a new institutional setup that would separate the commercial from the policy/regulatory/public goods functions. This proposed new institutional setup was preferred to the alternative of maintaining, and developing over the long-term, the Government line department for all forest and pasture activities. The separation will allow commercial forestry operations to be placed in a commercially oriented entity, tentatively named "Forest Corporation," where these functions can be performed in a more flexible, efficient and responsible way. Efficiency improvements would result in part from the pressures of a market economy, and in part from the participation of a broader range of stakeholders in the administration of natural resources who would be represented in the Corporation's Board of Directors. The key to success will be that this new entity (i) mainly acts as a management agent for the forest and pasture resources entrusted to it by the State and uses private sector contractors and services on a competitive basis for implementation of its operational plans; (ii) is directed by the stakeholders of the resources it exploits which not only include a broader range of Government agencies beyond the Ministry of Agriculture, but also the private sector, affected communes and villages, and NGOs; and (iii) maintains flexibility as to its structure, ownership and operational approaches to adjust to evolving changes of socio-economic and technical conditions. The creation of the proposed autonomous Forest Corporation will depend on the resolution of a number of current issues affecting the sector's efficiency which include the clarification and further improvement of the legal framework (forestry law, biodiversity law), implementation of policy reforms (control of illegal logging and introduction of improved forest management, competitive timber marketing and pricing, liberalization of timber trade, para. 3.9-3.11 below) and the establishment of an effective
 Albania Foreutry Project Page -17 - Staff Appraisal Report environmental management system (para. 3.6 below). The proposed separation of functions in the forest administration will also, on the other hand, allow concentration of non-commercial services in a smaller, tighter government line unit that ensures continuity of policies, regulatory control, provision of public services and funding of targeted interventions. In view of the uncertainties regarding the resolution of the current sector issues, project activities have been dimensioned and phased in a way that, except for development of institutions, staff and procedures and the implementation of pilot projects, the bulk of the investments in forest and civil works in the State forests and communes will be made after progress made in resolving the above sector constraints and in defining the future institutional structure has been assessed during the project's mid-term review (para. 4.12). During negotiations of the credit, agreement was reached on the phased approach for project implementation and the criteria and timing for the establishment of the future Forest Corporation. 3.4 Forest Corporation. At about the end of year three of the project, DGFP is expected to transform into a managerially and financially autonomous Forest Corporation (FC). FC would likely be established in accordance with Albania's Law on State Enterprises. It would operate along commercial principles and be principally responsible for the efficient management and exploitation of productive State forests and pastures. FC would retain the forest and pasture revenues that currently accrue to Treasury. FC would finance its operating and investment expenditures from these revenues, except for specific national development projects such as the Forestry Project, which would continue to be funded from the Treasury under contractual agreements. From its revenues, FC would make contributions to the Treasury in the form of a fixed annual fee (rent) or a variable charge for the products it sells based on volume or value (for instance, stumpage fee for timber, or royalty), to compensate the State for the use of nationally owned productive assets. Furthermore, FC would be expected to pay dividends to its shareholders (the Government and/or private investors) and corporate or income tax on its profits, currently 30 percent. FC would also be subject to the usual sales taxes or value added tax for its turnover. 3.5 Forest and Pasture Department. In parallel with the establishment of FC, administrative functions of policy development for the sector; regulatory control; planning, monitoring and evaluation of the sector's activities; provision of public services to sector agents (information, extension, education, research); management and assistance for communal forest and pastures; and protected areas management would continue as departmental Government services in a streamlined Forest and Pasture Department (FD) within the Ministry of Agriculture and Food (MAF) with funding provided from the central Government budget. 3.6 Forest Environmental Management. In addition to the above future structure of the forest administration, the project would establish within the Agricultural Program Office of MAF a Project Environmental Management Unit (PEMU) (see also para. 4.1 (c)) that would remain separate both from overall project management as well as from DGFP and the future FC. Its primary responsibility would be to promote the conservation of the nature in the forests by monitoring the implementation of the recommendations and mitigating measures under the Government endorsed Ecological Survey and Environmental Impact Assessment reports. To facilitate this task, PEMU would monitor environmental developments and adherence to standards in the forest and pasture sector, establish and operate an environmental data base for the sector, and prepare periodic status reports including a baseline report on environmental conditions of forests and pastures in Albania. It would also provide guidance and support to project management (Steering Committee and PMU, see para. 3.8, and 4.1(a) and (b) below) and to DGFP. Furthermore, PEMU will be used to channel technical assistance to the Committee for Environmental Protection under the Ministry of Health and Environment to help fulfil CEP's institutional role in respect of the project. Over time and in line with Government policies, PEMU would be expected to assume a broader environmental management responsibility for all of MAF's activities. During

Illegal timber and fuelwood harvesting activities have increased in some locations in recent years, resulting in revenue loss for the Government, wastage of timber, and devastation of harvesting areas. The current ban on the export of logs, poles, sawn wood and fuelwood (following a period of export quotas, licensing and export taxes until June 1995) limits the volume of forest sales, depresses domestic prices, and is thus one of the major factors preventing the sector from becoming financially viable. These conditions have contributed to the under-use of harvestable timber resources, low fiscal revenues and investment, and the preservation of wasteful and inefficient technologies. In order to facilitate more efficient use of Albania's forest resources and enhance the overall financial viability of the sector, exports of forest products should be fully liberalized by eliminating the existing trade ban. This liberalization would, however, be contingent upon DGFP regaining effective control over the forests (para. 3.9 above) and the updating of the annual allowable cut (AAC). Free external trade and competitive domestic marketing, combined with initial institutional reforms and strengthening to ensure environmentally sound and sustainable forest production, would lead to higher domestic prices (and higher marketed volume within the allowable cut). This in turn would allow to increase the floor price of stumpage, currently very low, and generate substantial additional fiscal revenue. While quantitative restrictions for exports of forest products would be eliminated (in effect, control of trade would be replaced by harvesting control in the forests), the re-emerging timber industry would continue to be protected by import tariffs on processed timber products. During negotiations of the credit agreement was reached that IDA and the Government would exchange views on the adequacy of DGFP's control over forest harvesting no later than during the project's mid-term project progress review (see also para. 4.12). FISCAL SUSTAINABILITY [See also Annex J of the Supporting Volume] 3.17 The forestry/pasture sector in the last years has been a drain on the Government's budget (para. 2.42). The policy reforms, institutional strengthening and initial investments supported under the project are expected to turn the situation around and generate increased revenues from forestry and pasture operations. A conservative estimate, based on income from timber and fuelwood revenues only,7 indicates that (i) the forestry sector's overall balance of total public income and expenditures could turn positive by 1998; (ii) the Treasury contribution to funding of DGFP's operating expenditure in the interim period would still be higher than the income Treasury will receive under the Revenue Account mechanism; however, the negative balance would decline over the period; and (iii) sector financial conditions could allow self-financing of a Forest Corporation from 1999 onwards. Treasury net income from forestry (the Corporation's forest royalties and taxes less continued budgetary support for the new Forest and Pasture Department), will sharply increase once the Corporation is operating on the basis of its own revenues without further budgetary support, except for project investments. In the longer term, assuming an annual allowable cut of 0.6 million m3 of industrial timber at an average price of $34 (i.e., 85 percent of the 1994 average stumpage price in Central Europe, or 2.6 times the 1994 price in Albania), potential annual gross proceeds on the order of $20 million could be expected over time from timber sales alone. 30-50 percent of this would accrue to Treasury from the Corporation's payments of royalties, dividends and profit taxes, making the forestry sector a major net contributor to the Government's budget, even if taking into account future budget expenditures for non-commercial activities of the FD and payments of interest/service charges and principal on the Italian soft loan and IDA credit for the project. PROJECT BENEFITS 5.1 In relation to the principal project objectives (para. 3. 1), the project's activities are expected to generate the following benefits: (i) economic production benefits from restoring degraded forest and pastures; (ii) direct and indirect environmental benefits from preventing losses from soil erosion, enhancing biodiversity and ecosystems protection, and preservation of protected areas; and (iii) institutional and policy improvements that are expected to lead to higher degrees of efficiency and sustainability of use of a public renewable resource, with provisions to safeguard stakeholder interests and the creation of positive externalities through continued, but more focused public sector involvement. Key indicators for progress would be: control of illegal harvesting operations; application of new-style forest management methodology that would be geared to multiple and sustainable forest use; annual total timber harvests not exceeding the AAC of net effective productive areas; achievement of the sector's financial viability which will depend on competitive marketing and trade liberalization; and creation of an autonomous Forest Corporation to deal with commercial, efficient exploitation of the resource. 5.2 Economic production benefits would accrue to the project from incremental investment in restoring and maintaining the production potential of forests and pastures; and more effective planning and management of its utilization. These benefits, in connection with the above institutional and policy reforms, are expected to improve the long term viability of the forest and pasture sector and would consist principally of: (a) Incremental wood productivity of State forests generated by the project through: (i) improved control of illegal cutting through DGFP's strengthened field services; (ii) halting degradation and improving management of existing forests, based on new forest management plans for 160,000 ha; (iii) reforestation by direct seeding or plantation on 1,000 ha of high forest areas in areas with expected high environmental benefits (clay soils on slopes), where no natural regeneration has been successfully established previously; (iv) pre-commercial thinnings on 29,000 ha; and (v) forest pest monitoring; (b) Incremental wood productivity of communally managed forest areas through: (i) reforestation of hilly/mountainous areas; and (ii) clear-cutting and temporary fencing of degraded shrub and coppice land to improve regrowth, mainly for fuelwood; (c) Increased production and productivity offodderfor livestock from communally managed forest and pasture areas through: (i) an increase of fodder yields of pasture land by fertilization, re-seeding and temporary fencing; (ii) the addition of fodder trees in pasture areas; (iii) the interplanting in shrub areas with fodder trees; (iv) the clearcutting and temporary fencing of shrubs to increase fodder yields (in addition to stimulate growth of fire wood -- see sub-para. (b) above). These increases in fodder availability will allow better feeding of the existing animal stocks, expand livestock numbers where the carrying capacity allows, and encourage change in the composition of livestock towards more

These changes will result in increased milk and meat production for subsistence and sales; (d) Incremental productivity of non-timber products through: (i) increased possibilities of hunting and tourism activities in State forests; (ii) collection, processing and marketing of medicinal plants, wild mushrooms, and berries from State forests; and (iii) the development of secondary forest product production from communal areas including aromatic, medicinal or cosmetic plants and mushroom cultures, as well as their local processing; and (e) Savings in lost production and productivity. Thanks to the expected impact of the project in curbing on-going degradation of forest and pastoral resources, additional economic benefits would be generated by foregoing lost production and productivity in wood, non- wood forest products, and fodder. All reforestation activities will take place in steep terrain where the risk for erosion is high. By re-establishing forest cover, with environmentally friendly methods, where most of the work is done manually, the risk of erosion is very much reduced. If these areas were not reforested, the bare land would be very vulnerable to erosion; (b) Water quality and retention. Continuous forest cover improves water quality and the capacity of the land to retain water, which is a very important function in many of the steep mountain areas of Albania; (c) Improved biodiversity of the forests. The reforestation sub-component has a strong element of improving the biodiversity of the state forests since the restoration of forest ecosystems, especially in areas with failed regeneration, would improve the conditions of the ground flora and create favorable habitats for wildlife; (d) Improved health of the forests. Improved management of forests in general, would improve the general health situation of the forests and the resistance to pest attacks; (e) Enhanced preservation of protected areas and one National Park for their biodiversity and other environmental values; and (f) Increased carbon absorption from faster tree growth and expansion of tree cover. 5.4 The institutional and policy development supported under the project would create an administrative and policy framework for a more efficient and sustainable use of State-owned forest and pasture assets, based on market values, competition, incentives, and environmental soundness. The project would build the base for placing commercially viable operations in the sector under an autonomous corporation and reorganizing the remaining functions of a public goods or general services character, including that of environmental management, under one or several Government agencies with transparent, full or partial, funding from the central budget.

MARKETS AND PRICES 5.5 In the immediate pre-project situation of the mid-1990s, the sustainable and technically feasible supply potential for industrial timber (annual allowable cut) exceeded the domestic demand, even taking into account significant illegal logging. The low demand is largely caused by the breakdown of timber processing industries during the transition from State-owned to private sector enterprises and by the quantitative restrictions and current ban on timber exports. Demand for fuelwood has, for a long time, exceeded the sustainable supply capacity due to a history of a subsidized and centrally administered distribution system. While the fuelwood subsidy was officially eliminated in 1994, the sales price has still been set by DGFP and not by market forces, and customary preferences are being accorded to villagers for their local fuelwood supply. These issues are expected to be resolved over the next few years: (a) A number of joint ventures with foreign partners have been established in the timber processing industry that are expected to improve capacity and technical efficiency; (b) an early action program to reduce illegal logging would be implemented under the project; (c) as part of the project's policy reform agenda, timber exports would be liberalized once control has been regained over illegal logging, allowing foreign sales of surplus timber at world market prices which are substantially higher than corresponding domestic prices before the project; and (d) the full liberalization of domestic fuelwood distribution and prices will tend to lift fuel wood prices closer to the price of alternative fuels such as electricity or kerosene. Furthermore, it can be expected that, regardless of price advantages of fuelwood, over time more convenient and attractive energy sources would be preferred as the economy

Legal sales of fuelwood have fallen to record lows in 1995 and 1996. 5.6 Forest production in Albania is largely geared towards serving the domestic demand. While beech wood, due to its high quality, appears to have good potential for export sales, the volumes available are uncertain as a result of the lack of volume assessments. However, the trade, pricing and marketing reforms proposed under the project would contribute to open up foreign markets and apply competitive pressures on forest production and processing enterprises that will all result in efficiency improvements. Domestic prices will be determined by demand and supply, using competitive bidding and auctions of standing timber as the main mechanisms. Over time domestic prices would thus adjust to their border equivalents. This will clear the markets and no major obstacles are therefore foreseen in terms of marketing the incremental wood production generated under the project's activities. 5.7 However, within this liberalized system of trade, pricing and marketing of forest products, interventions and regulations are needed in three principal aspects: (a) The total annual allowable cut for the productive areas that would be re-assessed under the project and regularly updated must not be exceeded by the harvesting volume in any one year to ensure sustainable forestry production; (b) harvesting must be done in accordance with new style forest management plans that ensure a sound spatial balance of harvesting and provide for the application of the results of environmental assessments for selecting the harvesting areas, the roads rehabilitation works, and the harvesting technology; and (c) auction of timber by the producing agency must have a pre-determined minimum price, below which sales would not take place since it could lead to 'mining" of the resource. T.his minimum price should be composed of two elements: (i) a royalty (a fixed fee per area or share of the minimum price) to be paid to the owner (the Albanian government) in compensation for the use of national assets (timber land and natural or previously planted forest) and the associated external benefits these assets generate; and (ii) the discounted cost of replacing the timber harvested, to be paid to the agency responsible for forest management. Reliable estimates of these values are not available or highly speculative. The economic analysis is therefore conservative and likely underestimates the total economic value of the project. 5.9 Results. The project is economically viable, both as a whole and by component (excluding the protected areas management component, which being a pilot project has not been valuated). Details of the economic analysis using "best estimates" of the technical and economic parameters, are given in Table 5.1 below. The project ERR, based on the aggregation of the individual component cost and net benefit streams, is estimated at 49 percent including the large and high-return road rehabilitation component. The very high returns from road rehabilitation is mainly due to the sunk cost of former road construction which is being exploited with relatively small rehabilitation expenditure, and because all of the wood that can be extracted is considered incremental. Excluding this road rehabilitation component, the ERR of the project would be 16 percent. Commercial reforestation of beech and black pine yielded an economic return of about 5 percent and failed to reach the threshold ERR level of 10 percent (opportunity cost of capital). During the project appraisal process, reforestation with native species was therefore excluded from project support, except for reforestation on highly erodible soils where the benefits from reduced soil erosion lifted the returns to above 10 percent. 5.10 Sensitivity. (i) The results of the economic analysis of timber production in the high forests are not sensitive against changes in costs and benefits. This is largely due to the very long term nature of the production cycle (80-100 years). (ii) For communal forest and pasture investments, most of which are maturing faster, in particular the pasture investments, the analysis results are more sensitive to changes in costs and benefits. However, even if costs are increased by 20% and benefits decreased by 20%, these investments do not loose economic viability. (iii) The investment in forest thinning generates a good economic return and remains viable over a relative wide range of changes of costs and benefits, since it improves the benefits from an existing, poorly exploited resource, i.e., existing forest stands. (iv) The investment in forest roads rehabilitation which shows very high returns under the basic assumptions used, remains viable under practically all circumstances. This is due to the sunk cost character of roads that were built earlier, the relative low investments needed for rehabilitation, and the attribution of the net value of all wood extracted from those areas as incremental benefits. (v) The benefits attributed to institutional development are based on the estimated value of the damages of illegal logging that would be prevented through institutional strengthening. This estimate is not based on detailed, comprehensive and reliable surveys but on observations of the affected areas and intensity of such damages. The value of the timber extracted illegally is not included in the damage estimate since this timber will not loose its economic value by being used outside the legal channels. The investments to help controlling illegal harvesting are only part of the costs included under institutional development, which cover for instance the costs of all technical assistance, project management, education, training and research. The effectiveness of the measures to ensure efficient forest management, initially mainly through the reduction of illegal logging, is the most sensitive element of the project's justification. This reduction can only be achieved over time and with initial investments in equipment and training. Should the reduction in illegal logging not be possible during the first half of the project period, the justification for continuing with project investments would be lost.

RISKS 5.11 Project risks regarding technical aspects of forest management, road rehabilitation and communal forest and pasture management are considered low. Albania possesses the basic expertise to deal with technical aspects of forest use. Safeguards are built into the project that require modern forest management planning methodology, environmental assessment and mitigating procedures, and regulations concerning transfer and use of communal forest and pasture areas are in place before disbursements for investments in these activities are made. 5.12 The main risks of the project relate to uncertainties about the implementation of the institutional and policy reforms. Critical elements are the following. First, the State must regain control over forest management and exploitation. Albania's forest resource is characterized by public ownership, an extremely long production cycle, and the generation of important, though not easily quantifiable, environmental and other external benefits. Without effective protection and management of the forests the benefits expected from investments in forest and road works cannot materialize. To this end, the project focuses on the implementation of a monitorable action plan to reduce illegal logging and the early strengthening of the administrative capacity through the provision of physical inputs and staff reorientation and training. It will also include more effective involvement of a broader range of stakeholders and of affected communes and populations. Second, and building on progress made in forest protection, is the need to achieve financial viability and sustainability within the sector, at least for its commercial operations. To this end, market-oriented procedures, both in domestic marketing and external trade, would be introduced to help overcome the current under-use and under-valuation of the forest resource, while at the same time ensuring technically and environmentally sound procedures of exploitation. Third,
 Albania Forestry Project Page -49 - Staff Appraisal Report and depending on progress made in achieving both technical and financial viability, is the need to improve the technical and economic efficiency of forest and pasture operations. To this end, the project would support the separation of commercial forest and pasture operations from regulatory and policy activities. The former are expected to become the responsibility of a financially autonomous enterprise, the Forest Corporation, and the latter services would remain within a line department of the Ministry of Agriculture. 5.13 At the start of the project, these three critical elements presenting major risks are not in place since investment and time are required to build competence and implement these actions. The risk to achieve the policy and institutional goals is mitigated by allowing a relative long adjustment and reform period of up to three years. This first half of the project period would be used to build capacity for dealing with the issues, achieve consensus within Albania about the longer term arrangements for use of the forest and pasture resources, and refine concepts and planning for the policy, legal and institutional actions. This process would be facilitated and smoothened by a proposed high-level seminar in year two to review strategies proposed for the development of the sector, and the mid-term review of the project. The latter would be used to assess progress made in resolving the above critical aspects and, depending on the outcome and achievements, to confirm or adjust the design and scope of project activities, in particular the more heavy forest and road rehabilitation investments, as well as communal investments, planned for the second half of the project. Firmness in decision making as well as flexibility in project implementation would be further enhanced by the high level of authority given to the institutional arrangements for project management and the use of annual work programming, budgeting and contracting procedures for project implementation activities.

doc.abstracts: The three principal objectives of the Forestry Project are to: 1) restore degraded state-owned forest and pasture areas and promote their sustainable use; 2) promote conservation of natural forest ecosystems; and 3) take the initial steps in the transition of the forestry/pasture sector to a market economy, separating commercial from regulatory functions and establishing mechanisms for self-financing of the commercial activities. The project will support institutional and policy reforms of Albania's forest and pasture sector and provide resources for investment in the following five main components: 1) institutional development of the forest/pasture administration including related training, education and research and the establishment of a project environmental management unit; 2) improved management of state forests; 3) rehabilitation of forest roads; 4) management of communal forest and pasture areas; and 5) management of protected areas.
